publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Potential years of life lost (PYLL) from causes considered amenable to healthcare - adults (NHSOF 1a.i)
description: The number of years of life lost by every 100,000 adults aged 20 and over dying from a condition which is usually treatable, measured in a way which allows for comparisons between populations with different age profiles and over time.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Potential years of life lost (PYLL) from causes considered amenable to healthcare - children and young people (NHSOF 1a.ii)
description: The number of years of life lost by every 100,000 persons aged 0 to 19 dying from a condition which is usually treatable, measured in a way which allows for comparisons between populations with different age profiles and over time.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Life expectancy at 75 (NHSOF 1b)
description:
The average 
 number 

 of additional years a man or woman aged 75 can be expected to live if they continue to live in the same place and the death rates in their area remain the same for the rest of their life.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Neonatal mortality and stillbirths (former indicator 1.6.ii) (NHSOF 1c)
description: The number of babies stillborn or dying before 28 days old per 1,000 live births and stillbirths.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Under 75 mortality rate from cardiovascular disease (NHSOF 1.1)
description:
Directly standardised mortality rate from cardiovascular disease for people aged under 75, per 100,000 population.



Direct comparison with previous year’s mortality, prior to 2011, is not advisable. There was a decrease in the number of deaths with an underlying cause coded as ‘Cardiovascular Disease’. However, a large proportion of this decrease is caused by a correction to the coding of vascular dementia, which was coded as underlying cause CVD (I67.9) until 2010 and is now coded as underlying cause in ‘Mental Health’ deaths (F01). Further details can be found at: http://www.ons.gov.uk/ons/rel/subnational-health3/results-of-the-icd-10-v2010-bridge-coding-study--england-and-wales--2009/2009/index.html

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Under 75 mortality rate from respiratory disease (NHSOF 1.2)
description: Directly standardised mortality rate from respiratory disease for people aged under 75, per 100,000 population.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Under 75 mortality rate from liver disease (NHSOF 1.3)
description: Directly standardised mortality rate from liver disease for people aged under 75, per 100,000 population.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Under 75 mortality rate from cancer (NHSOF 1.4)
description: Directly standardised mortality rate from cancer for people aged under 75, per 100,000 population.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: One-year survival from all cancers (NHSOF 1.4.i)
description:
A measure of the number of adults diagnosed with any type of cancer in a year who are still alive one year after diagnosis.



ONS still publish survival percentages for individual types of cancers. These can be found at: http://www.ons.gov.uk/ons/rel/cancer-unit/cancer-survival/cancer-survival-in-england--patients-diagnosed-2007-2011-and-followed-up-to-2012/index.html

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Five-year survival from all cancers (NHSOF 1.4.ii)
description:
A measure of the number of adults diagnosed with any type of cancer in a year who are still alive five years after diagnosis.



ONS still publish survival percentages for individual types of cancers. These can be found at: http://www.ons.gov.uk/ons/rel/cancer-unit/cancer-survival/cancer-survival-in-england--patients-diagnosed-2007-2011-and-followed-up-to-2012/index.html

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: One-year survival from breast, lung and colorectal cancer (NHSOF 1.4.iii)
description:
A measure of the number of adults diagnosed with breast, lung or colorectal cancer in a year who are still alive one year after diagnosis.



ONS still publish survival percentages for individual types of cancers. These can be found at: http://www.ons.gov.uk/ons/rel/cancer-unit/cancer-survival/cancer-survival-in-england--patients-diagnosed-2007-2011-and-followed-up-to-2012/index.html



A time series for one-year survival figures for breast, lung and colorectal cancer individually (previous NHS Outcomes Framework indicators 1.4.i, 1.4.iii and 1.4.v) is still published and can be found under the link Indicator data - previous methodology (.xls) below.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Five-year survival from breast, lung and colorectal cancer (NHSOF 1.4.iv)
description:
A measure of the number of adults diagnosed with breast, lung or colorectal cancer in a year who are still alive five years after diagnosis.



ONS still publish survival percentages for individual types of cancers. These can be found at: http://www.ons.gov.uk/ons/rel/cancer-unit/cancer-survival/cancer-survival-in-england--patients-diagnosed-2007-2011-and-followed-up-to-2012/index.html



A time series for five-year survival figures for breast, lung and colorectal cancer individually (previous NHS Outcomes Framework indicators 1.4.ii, 1.4.iv and 1.4.vi) is still published and can be found under the link Indicator data - previous methodology (.xls) below.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Excess under 75 mortality rate in adults with serious mental illness (formerly indicator 1.5) (NHSOF 1.5.i)
description: A measure of the extent to which adults with a serious mental illness die younger than adults in the general population.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16
Mental health and mortality data linkage specification

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Infant mortality (NHSOF 1.6.i)
description: Infant mortality is defined as the number of babies dying before the age of one for every 1,000 live births.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Five-year survival from all cancers in children (formerly indicator 1.6.iii) (NHSOF 1.6.ii)
description: A measure of the proportion of children diagnosed with any type of cancer in a year who are still alive five years after diagnosis.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Health-related quality of life for people with long-term conditions (NHSOF 2)
description: This indicator measures the health-related quality of life for people who identify themselves as having one or more long-term conditions.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Proportion of people feeling supported to manage their condition (NHSOF 2.1)
description: This indicator measures the degree to which people with health conditions that are expected to last for a significant period of time feel they have had sufficient support from relevant services and organisations to manage their condition.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Employment of people with long-term conditions (NHSOF 2.2)
description: The percentage difference between the rate of employment in the general population of working age (16-64) and the rate of employment amongst adults of working age with a long-term condition.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Unplanned hospitalisation for chronic ambulatory care sensitive conditions (NHSOF 2.3.i)
description: This indicator measures how many people with specific long-term conditions, which should not normally require hospitalisation, are admitted to hospital in an emergency. These conditions include, for example, diabetes, epilepsy and high blood pressure.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Unplanned hospitalisation for asthma, diabetes and epilepsy in under 19s (NHSOF 2.3.ii)
description: This indicator measures how many young people (aged 0-18 inclusive) who have asthma, diabetes or epilepsy are admitted to hospital in an emergency.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Health-related quality of life for carers (NHSOF 2.4)
description: This indicator measures health-related quality of life for people who identify themselves as helping or supporting family members, friends, neighbours or others with their long-term physical or mental illness/disability or because of problems related to old age.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Employment of people with mental illness (formerly indicator 2.5) (NHSOF 2.5.i)
description: The percentage difference between the rate of employment in the general population of working age (16-64) and the rate of employment amongst adults of working age with a mental illness.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Estimated diagnosis rate for people with dementia (NHSOF 2.6.i)
description: This indicator measures the number of people that have been diagnosed with dementia as a proportion of the number who are estimated to have the condition.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Emergency admissions for acute conditions that should not usually require hospital admission (NHSOF 3a)
description: The indicator measures the number of emergency admissions to hospital in England for acute conditions such as ear/nose/throat infections, kidney/urinary tract infections and heart failure, among others, that could potentially have been avoided if the patient had been better managed in primary care.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Emergency readmissions within 30 days of discharge from hospital (NHSOF 3b)
description: This indicator measures the percentage of admissions of people who returned to hospital as an emergency within 30 days of the last time they left hospital after a stay. Admissions for cancer and obstetrics are excluded as they may be part of the patient’s care plan.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Emergency admissions for children with lower respiratory tract infections (LRTIs) (NHSOF 3.2)
description: This indicator measures the number of emergency admissions to hospital of children with selected types of lower respiratory tract infections (bronchiolitis, bronchopneumonia and pneumonia).

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Hip fracture: Proportion of patients recovering to their previous levels of mobility / walking ability at 30 days (NHSOF 3.5.i)
description: The proportion of patients, expressed as a percentage, with a hip fracture recovering to their previous levels of mobility at 30 days.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Hip fracture: Proportion of patients recovering to their previous levels of mobility / walking ability at 120 days (NHSOF 3.5.ii)
description: The proportion of patients, expressed as a percentage, with a hip fracture recovering to their previous levels of mobility at 120 days.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Proportion of older people (65 and over) who were still at home 91 days after discharge from hospital into reablement/rehabilitation services (NHSOF 3.6.i)
description: The proportion of older people (aged 65 and over), expressed as a percentage, who, after a period of reablement/rehabilitation, maintain their independence by remaining or returning to their home or previous residence 91 days after leaving hospital.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Proportion of older people (65 and over) who were offered rehabilitation following discharge from acute or community hospital (NHSOF 3.6.ii)
description: The proportion of older people (aged 65 and over), expressed as a percentage, who are offered reablement services when they leave hospital.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Patient experience of GP services (NHSOF 4a.i)
description: This indicator measures the weighted percentage of people who report their overall experience of GP services as ‘fairly good’ or ‘very good’.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Patient experience of GP out-of-hours services (NHSOF 4a.ii)
description: This indicator measures the weighted percentage of people who report their overall experience of GP out-of-hours services as ‘fairly good’ or ‘very good’.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Patient experience of dental services (NHSOF 4a.iii)
description: This indicator measures the weighted percentage of people who report their overall experience of NHS dental services as ‘fairly good’ or ‘very good’.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Patient experience of hospital care (NHSOF 4b)
description: Patient experience measured by scoring the results of a selection of questions from the National Inpatient Survey looking at a range of elements of hospital care.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Patient experience of outpatient services (NHSOF 4.1)
description: Patient experience measured by scoring the results of a selection of questions from the National Outpatient Survey.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Responsiveness to inpatients’ personal needs (NHSOF 4.2)
description: Patient experience measured by scoring the results of a selection of questions from the National Inpatient Survey focussing on the responsiveness to personal needs.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Patient experience of A&E services (NHSOF 4.3)
description: Patient experience measured by scoring the results of a selection of questions from the National Accident and Emergency (A&E) Department Survey.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Access to GP services (NHSOF 4.4.i)
description: This indicator measures the weighted percentage of people who report their experience of making a GP appointment as ‘fairly good’ or ‘very good’.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Access to NHS dental services (NHSOF 4.4.ii)
description: This indicator measures the weighted percentage of people who reported that they were successful in getting an NHS dental appointment when they tried in the last two years.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Women’s experience of maternity services (NHSOF 4.5)
description: Patient experience of maternity services measured by scoring the results of a selection of questions from the National Maternity Services Survey.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Bereaved carers view on the quality of care in the last 3 months of life (NHSOF 4.6)
description: This indicator measures the experience of care for people at the end of their lives, based on the views of bereaved carers, from the National Bereavement Survey (VOICES).

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Patient experience of community mental health services (NHSOF 4.7)
description: This indicator measures patient experience of community mental health services based on selected questions from the National Community Mental Health Survey.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Deaths from venous thromboembolism (VTE) related events within 90 days post discharge from hospital (NHSOF 5.1)
description: The indicator measures the number of patients who have been admitted to hospital with any cause and die within 90 days of their last discharge from a VTE related event, expressed as a rate per 100,000 adult hospital admissions.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Incidence of healthcare-associated infection - MRSA (NHSOF 5.2.i)
description: The number of Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) bloodstream infections reported to Public Health England (PHE).

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Incidence of healthcare-associated infection - C. difficile (NHSOF 5.2.ii)
description: The number of Clostridium difficile infections reported to Public Health England (PHE), in patients aged two years or older.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Admission of full-term babies to neonatal care (NHSOF 5.5)
description: The number of full-term babies (gestation greater than 36 weeks) admitted within 28 days of birth to a neonatal unit, expressed as a percentage of all full-term births.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Patient safety incidents reported (formerly indicators 5a, 5b and 5.4) (NHSOF 5.6)
description:
The number of patient safety incidents reported to the National Reporting and Learning System (NRLS) by provider organisations, per 100,000 population.

A patient safety incident is defined as ‘any unintended or unexpected incident(s) that could have, or did, lead to harm for one or more person(s) receiving NHS funded healthcare’.

references.title: DH Guidance for the NHS Outcomes Framework 2015/16

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Potential years of life lost (PYLL) from causes considered amenable to healthcare (retired as of May-15) (NHSOF 1a)
description:
The number of years of life lost by every 100,000 persons dying from a condition which is usually treatable, measured in a way which allows for comparisons between populations with different age profiles and over time.



Please note that this indicator has been retired as of May 2015. This is because the PYLL from causes considered amenable to healthcare for all ages does not appear in the 2015/16 NHS Outcomes Framework. For Potential years of life lost (PYLL) from causes considered amenable to healthcare for adults or children and young people please see indicators 1a.i and 1a.ii.

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Total health gain as assessed by patients for elective procedures (retired as of May-15) (NHSOF 3.1)
description:
Total health gain from patients who reported an improvement in health status following an elective procedure. The four indicators cover groin hernia, hip replacements, knee replacements and varicose veins.



Please note that these indicators have been retired as of May 2015. This is because the four indicators reporting the total health gain on seperate procedures have been combined into one indicator (Total health gain as assessed by patients for physical health-related procedures) in the 2015/16 NHS Outcomes Framework. This newly combined indicator is currently a placeholder and has yet to be developed.

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: Incidence of harm to children due to ‘failure to monitor’ (retired as of May-15) (NHSOF 5.6)
description:
The total number of safety incidents, causing harm to children due to failure to monitor, reported to the National Reporting and Learning System (NRLS) by provider organisations.



Please note that this indicator has been retired as of May 2015. This is because it has been removed form the 2015/16 NHS Outcomes Framework due to the unsuitable data source and the unavailability of alternative data sources on which the indicator could be based. There were also some technical issues with the calculation methodology.

publisher.name: Health and Social Care Information Centre

title: ZZZTest Additional indicator
description:
The total number of safety incidents, causing harm to children due to failure to monitor, reported to the National Reporting and Learning System (NRLS) by provider organisations.



Please note that this indicator has been retired as of May 2015. This is because it has been removed form the 2015/16 NHS Outcomes Framework due to the unsuitable data source and the unavailability of alternative data sources on which the indicator could be based. There were also some technical issues with the calculation methodology.
